segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
8. Itchy
82. A Full Moon Night

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde mahatā bhikkhusaṃghena saddhiṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā bhikkhusaṃghaparivuto ajjhokāse nisinno hoti.
segments.en: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

segments.pli: “puccheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ, sace me bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sake āsane nisīditvā puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā sake āsane nisīditvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” replied that mendicant. He took his seat and said to the Buddha:
“Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates, that is:
form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
“Yes, they are,” replied the Buddha.

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:
“But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”
“These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.” …

segments.pli: taññeva nu kho, bhante, upādānaṃ te pañcupādānakkhandhā udāhu aññatra pañcahi upādānakkhandhehi upādānan”ti?
segments.en: “But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”

segments.pli: “Na kho, bhikkhu, taññeva upādānaṃ te pañcupādānakkhandhā nāpi aññatra pañcahi upādānakkhandhehi upādānaṃ, api ca yo tattha chandarāgo taṃ tattha upādānan”ti.
segments.en: “Neither. Rather, the desire and greed for them is the grasping there.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant asked another question:
“But sir, can there be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”
“There can,” said the Buddha.
“It’s when someone thinks:

segments.pli: ‘evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃvedano siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsañño siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti.
segments.en: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, or such consciousness!’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, siyā pañcupādānakkhandhesu chandarāgavemattatā”ti?
segments.en: That’s how there can be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant asked another question:
“Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati rūpakkhandho.
segments.en: “Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.
Any kind of feeling at all …
Any kind of perception at all …
Any kind of choices at all …

segments.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati viññāṇakkhandho.
segments.en: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.
That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant asked another question:

segments.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya;
segments.en: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found?

segments.pli: ko hetu ko paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya;
segments.en: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling …

segments.pli: ko hetu ko paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya;
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: ko hetu ko paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya;
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: ko hetu ko paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti?
segments.en: consciousness is found?”

segments.pli: “Cattāro kho, bhikkhu, mahābhūtā hetu, cattāro mahābhūtā paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
segments.en: “The four primary elements are the reason why the aggregate of form is found.

segments.pli: Phasso hetu phasso paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
segments.en: Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling,

segments.pli: Phasso hetu phasso paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
segments.en: perception,

segments.pli: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
segments.en: and choices are found.

segments.pli: Nāmarūpaṃ hetu, nāmarūpaṃ paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti.
segments.en: Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant asked another question:
“Sir, how does identity view come about?”

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
segments.en: “It’s because an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.

segments.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
segments.en: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
They regard feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
segments.en: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
That’s how identity view comes about.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant … asked another question:
“But sir, how does identity view not come about?”

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
segments.en: It’s because an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.

segments.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
segments.en: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
They don’t regard feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; na attani vā viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
segments.en: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sakkāyadiṭṭhi na hotī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how identity view does not come about.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu … pe … apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant … asked another question:

segments.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, rūpassa assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ;
segments.en: “Sir, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,

segments.pli: ko viññāṇassa assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
segments.en: and consciousness?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—ayaṃ rūpassa assādo.
segments.en: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.

segments.pli: Yaṃ rūpaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ—ayaṃ rūpassa ādīnavo.
segments.en: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

segments.pli: Yo rūpasmiṃ chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ—idaṃ rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ.
segments.en: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.
The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: yaṃ viññāṇaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—ayaṃ viññāṇassa assādo.
segments.en: consciousness: this is its gratification.

segments.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ—ayaṃ viññāṇassa ādīnavo.
segments.en: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

segments.pli: Yo viññāṇasmiṃ chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ—idaṃ viññāṇassa nissaraṇan”ti.
segments.en: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.”

segments.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
segments.en: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:

segments.pli: “Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
segments.en: “One truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
They truly see any kind of feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
segments.en: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no ego, possessiveness, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and all external stimuli.”

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: Now at that time one of the mendicants had the thought:

segments.pli: “iti kira bho rūpaṃ anattā, vedanā … saññā … saṅkhārā … viññāṇaṃ anattā;
segments.en: “So it seems, good sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa bhikkhuno cetasā ceto parivitakkamaññāya bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, knowing what that monk was thinking, addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco moghapuriso avidvā avijjāgato taṇhādhipateyyena cetasā satthusāsanaṃ atidhāvitabbaṃ maññeyya.
segments.en: “It’s possible that some foolish person here—unknowing and ignorant, their mind dominated by craving—thinks they can overstep the teacher’s instructions. They think:

segments.pli: ‘Iti kira, bho, rūpaṃ anattā, vedanā … saññā … saṅkhārā … viññāṇaṃ anattā.
segments.en: ‘So it seems, good sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?’

segments.pli: Paṭipucchāvinītā kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, tatra tatra tesu tesu dhammesu.
segments.en: Now, mendicants, you have been educated by me in questioning with regards to all these things in all such cases.
What do you think, mendicants?
Is form permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”
“Is feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
“Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
“No, sir.”
“So you should truly see …
Seeing this …
They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
“Two on the aggregates; exactly the same; and can there be;
on the term; and on the cause;
two questions on identity;
gratification; and that with consciousness:
these are the ten questions
the mendicant came to ask.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī…

suttaplex.blurb: On a sabbath day with the Sangha at Sāvatthi, the Buddha answers a series of ten questions on the aggregates.
